title: Terraform Basics
description: Learn Infrastructure as Code fundamentals with Terraform.

cards.front: What are the main Terraform workflow steps?
cards.back: Write → Init → Plan → Apply → Destroy. Write configuration, initialize providers, preview changes, apply infrastructure, and optionally destroy resources.
Initializes a Terraform working directory by downloading provider plugins and setting up the backend for state storage.
Stores the current state of managed infrastructure, mapping real-world resources to configuration. Critical for tracking changes.

cards.front: What's the difference between 'terraform plan' and 'terraform apply'?
cards.back: plan shows a preview of changes without applying them; apply executes the changes and updates infrastructure.
Plugins that enable Terraform to interact with cloud platforms, SaaS providers, and APIs (e.g., AWS, Azure, Kubernetes).
A reusable collection of Terraform configuration files in a directory. Modules enable code organization and reusability.
Input parameters that allow customization of infrastructure without modifying source code. Defined with 'variable' blocks.

cards.front: What's the difference between local and remote backends?
cards.back: Local stores state on disk; remote stores state in a shared location (S3, Terraform Cloud) enabling team collaboration.
terraform import <resource_type>.<name> <id> - Brings existing resources under Terraform management.
Values exported from Terraform configuration, useful for displaying info or passing to other modules/scripts.
Formats Terraform configuration files to a canonical style for consistency and readability.

cards.front: What are data sources in Terraform?
cards.back: Allow Terraform to fetch information from external sources or existing infrastructure without managing it.
Marks a resource for destruction and recreation on the next apply. Useful when a resource is damaged or needs replacement.
Execute scripts or commands on resources during creation/destruction. Use as a last resort; prefer cloud-init or config management.
Lock file that records exact provider versions used, ensuring consistent provider versions across team members.
Checks configuration files for syntax errors and internal consistency without accessing remote services.
